name: Kusner conjecture
rephrased: The maximum number of points that can be placed in d-dimensional Euclidean space such that all pairs of points are at the same distance from each other is d+1.
implication_form: If a set of points in d-dimensional Euclidean space exists where all pairs are equidistant, then the size of this set is at most d+1.
explained: The Kusner conjecture concerns the maximum size of equilateral sets in Euclidean space. An equilateral set is a set of points where all pairwise distances are equal. The conjecture states that the equilateral dimension of d-dimensional Euclidean space (\(\mathbb{R}^d\)) is exactly d+1. This means that the largest possible equilateral set in \(\mathbb{R}^d\) has d+1 points, and such a set exists (e.g., the vertices of a regular simplex). While it is known that d+1 is achievable, the conjecture asserts that no larger equilateral set exists in any dimension d > 1.
